info.author: Martijn Faassen
info.description:
more.whytool: find out what code was responsible for generating a response
==========================================================================

``more.whytool`` lets you create a tool that tells you what view code
was responsible for handling a request.

To create such a tool you do the following, for instance in the
``main.py`` of your project::

  from more.whytool import why_tool
  from .someplace import SomeApp

  def my_why_tool():
      SomeApp.commit()
      why_tool(SomeApp)

where ``SomeApp`` is the application you want to query, typically the
root application of your project.

Now you need to hook it up in ``setup.py`` to you can have the tool
available::

    entry_points={
        'console_scripts': [
            'morewhytool = myproject.main:my_why_tool',
        ]
    },

After you install your project, you should now have a ``morewhytool``
tool available. You can give it requests::

  $ morewhytool /some/path

It tells you:

* What path directive handled the request.

* What view directive handled the request.

CHANGES
*******

0.5 (2017-01-13)
================

- Initial public release.
info.name: more.whytool
info.summary: What code was responsible for generating a view
info.html_description:
more.whytool: find out what code was responsible for generating a response

more.whytool lets you create a tool that tells you what view code was responsible for handling a request.

To create such a tool you do the following, for instance in the main.py of your project:

from more.whytool import why_tool
from .someplace import SomeApp

def my_why_tool():
    SomeApp.commit()
    why_tool(SomeApp)

where SomeApp is the application you want to query, typically the root application of your project.

Now you need to hook it up in setup.py to you can have the tool available:

entry_points={
    'console_scripts': [
        'morewhytool = myproject.main:my_why_tool',
    ]
},

After you install your project, you should now have a morewhytool tool available. You can give it requests:

$ morewhytool /some/path

It tells you:

  • What path directive handled the request.
  • What view directive handled the request.

CHANGES

0.5 (2017-01-13)

  • Initial public release.
